rpFBA’s documentation!¶

Indices and tables¶

Introduction¶

Welcome to the documentation of rpFBA. The project uses the rpBase project to merge a rpSBML file and a SBML files to simulate FBA using CobraPy. The project supports the “fraction of reaction”, standard FBA and parsimonious FBA.

Usage¶

First build the rpBase and rpCache dockers before building the local docker:

docker build -t brsynth/rpfba-standalone:v2 -f Dockerfile .

To call the docker locally you can use the following command:

python run.py -input /path/to/file -input_format tar -gem_sbml /path/to/file -output /path/to/output

API¶

class rpTool.rpFBA(rpsbml)¶

Bases: object

Class to simulate an rpsbml object using different FBA types and objective functions

runFBA(reaction_id, coefficient=1.0, is_max=True, pathway_id='rp_pathway', objective_id=None)¶

Run FBA using a single objective

Parameters

  • reaction_id (str) – The id of the reactions involved in the objective

  • coefficient (float) – The coefficient associated with the reactions id (Default: 1.0)

  • is_max (bool) – Maximise or minimise the objective (Default: True)

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway (Default: rp_pathway)

  • objective_id (str) – Overwrite the default id (Default: None)

Returns

Tuple with the results of the FBA and boolean indicating the success or failure of the function

Return type

tuple

runFractionReaction(source_reaction, source_coefficient, target_reaction, target_coefficient, fraction_of_source=0.75, is_max=True, pathway_id='rp_pathway', objective_id=None)¶

Optimise for a target reaction while fixing a source reaction to the fraction of its optimum

Parameters

  • source_reaction (str) – The id of the source reaction

  • source_coefficient (float) – The source coefficient associated with the source reaction id

  • target_reaction (str) – The id of the target reaction

  • target_coefficient (float) – The source coefficient associated with the target reaction id

  • fraction_of_optimum (float) – Between 0.0 and 1.0 determining the fraction of optimum (Default: 0.75)

  • is_max (bool) – Maximise or minimise the objective (Default: True)

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway (Default: rp_pathway)

  • objective_id (str) – Overwrite the default id (Default: None)

Returns

Tuple with the results of the FBA and boolean indicating the success or failure of the function

Return type

tuple

runMultiObjective(reactions, coefficients, is_max=True, pathway_id='rp_pathway', objective_id=None)¶

Run FBA using multiple objectives

Parameters

  • reactions (list) – The ids of the reactions involved in the objective

  • coefficients (list) – The coefficients associated with the reactions id

  • is_max (bool) – Maximise or minimise the objective (Default: True)

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway (Default: rp_pathway)

  • objective_id (str) – Overwrite the default id (Default: None)

Returns

Success or failure of the function

Return type

bool

runParsimoniousFBA(reaction_id, coefficient=1.0, fraction_of_optimum=0.95, is_max=True, pathway_id='rp_pathway', objective_id=None)¶

Run parsimonious FBA using a single objective

Parameters

  • reaction_id (str) – The id of the reactions involved in the objective

  • coefficient (float) – The coefficient associated with the reactions id (Default: 1.0)

  • fraction_of_optimum (float) – Between 0.0 and 1.0 determining the fraction of optimum (Default: 0.95)

  • is_max (bool) – Maximise or minimise the objective (Default: True)

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway (Default: rp_pathway)

  • objective_id (str) – Overwrite the default id (Default: None)

Returns

Tuple with the results of the FBA and boolean indicating the success or failure of the function

writeAnalysisResults(objective_id, cobra_results, pathway_id='rp_pathway')¶

Method to harcode into BRSynth annotations the results of a COBRA analysis

Parameters

  • objective_id (str) – The id of the objective to optimise

  • cobra_results (cobra.ModelSummary) – The cobrapy results object

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway group (Default: rp_pathway)

Returns

None

Return type

None

class run.main(inputfile, input_format, gem_sbml, output, pathway_id='rp_pathway', species_group_id='central_species', sink_species_group_id='rp_sink_species', objective_id='None', compartment_id='MNXC3', sim_type='fraction', source_reaction='biomass', target_reaction='RP1_sink', source_coefficient=1.0, target_coefficient=1.0, num_workers=10, is_max=True, fraction_of=0.75, dont_merge=True)¶

Single rpSBML simulation

Parameters

  • inputfile (str) – Path to the input file

  • input_format (str) – Input file format. Valid inputs are: tar, sbml

  • gem_sbml (str) – Path to the GEM file

  • output (str) – The path to the output file. Note that it will be the file type defined as input_format

  • pathway_id (str) – The id of the heterologous pathway (Default: rp_pathway)

  • species_group_id (str) – The id of the central species (Default: central_species)

  • sink_species_group_id (str) – The id of the sink species (Default: rp_sink_species)

  • objective_id (str) – Overwrite the auto-generated id of the results (Default: None)

  • compartment_id (str) – The SBML compartment id (Default: MNXC3)

  • sim_type (str) – The type of simulation to use. Available simulation types include: fraction, fba, rpfba

  • source_reaction (str) – The reaction id of the source reaction.

  • target_reaction (str) – The reaction id of the target reaction. Note that if fba or rpfba options are used, then these are ignored

  • source_coefficient (float) – The source coefficient

  • target_coefficient (float) – The target coefficient

  • num_workers (int) – Number of multiprocessors workers

  • is_max (bool) – Maximise or minimise the objective

  • fraction_of (float) – The fraction of the optimum. Note that this value is ignored is fba is used

  • dont_merge (bool) – Output the merged model (Default: True)

Returns

None

Return type

None

rpFBA
